Area para el botón de ejecutar y tal vez mensajes al usuario
Use the blocks to control the Robot

Welcome to your first mission.

You must create a program for the Robot.
To create a program you have to drag the command blocks and connect them under the Start block.

You are going to use the first type of command block: Move.

The Robot has to get to the start to accomplish the mission.

But careful! the Robot must stay within the colored square area.

Let's go and get the star! And you will be able to use new blocks in the next mission.
Drag the Move block under the Start block and press RUN
Now let\'s try the speed command block..\n\nCreate a program that gets the Robot to the star again, but this time make it go faster than last time.
Oh, you forgot to make to Robot faster.\n\nTry again!

In this mission you have two new command blocks to use and they can work together: Wait y Number.

Wait does just that, it makes the Robot wait. The number block is a sensor, this means the Robot can detect what number has been pressed. Sensor blocks connect differently, they connect to the right of some blocks. Their shape gives you a hint.

Your mission is to create a program so that the Robot moves towards the star once it has waited for you to press the number 5 button.
The Robot has to wait until you press number five. Then he has to go to the target.\n\nThere is a hint in these words: wait, number 5, move...
I can repeat, repeat, repeat comands

In this new mission you are going to get three new command blocks: Repeat, Color and Position.

Repeat is a special command: it makes the Robot repeat all the commands it connects. If you want a command to be repeated place it under a Repeat block.

Color: the Robot has a color sensor that detects the color of the floor tile he is standing in. You can use the Color command block to tell the Robot what color you want to detect in your program.

Position: will make the Robot jump from one square to another. The Robot's floor is a square matrix of 5 squares wide times 5 squares tall. The Robot understands the position of the first square as 1,1 and the last one is 5,5.. going through 1,2 and 1,3... if you give it a try you will understand.

The mission is to go to the red square and then end up on the square with the star.
First the Robot has to get to the red square. Then he has to change his position to the first block. If you count the squares you can calculate the position. The first square is 1,1.
You have made the Robot get to all the targets, but you can do this making a program using all the types of command blocks you have available.\n\nCan you imagine how the program would be?
That was great! Ready for the next mission?
I can\'t get to that color!!

FiPL "My First Programming Language" is an app to learn to program.

You will discover different commands to move the Robot around it's stage.

To create a progam you have to drag a command block from the center panel to under the Start block.

You can reorder the commands and drag them to the waste bin to delete them.
To make the Robot start your program press the "RUN" button.

The Robot will show you it's programming logs. This is very useful information to a programmer: if the program doesn't go like you imagined you can try and see why by reading the log.
You can turn the panel to see the Robot's log or go back to the blocks by using the buttons on the menu bar at the top of the screen.

I recommend that you use the missions to learn the commands. You can read the missions and load them from the Missions screen, available from menu at the top of the main screen.

These are the types of blocks you can use:
This is the MOVE command block.\nYou can drag it and connect it under other blocks.\nYou can press the arrow and change the direction you want the Robot to move: up, down, left or right.

This is the WAIT command block.
You can drag it and connect it under other blocks.
This command will make the Robot pause it's program and wait. You have to give it some event so that it can continue it's program. To do so you can use a sensor command block.
To learn how to use this block I recommend Mission Three.

This is the POSITION command block.
You can drag it and connect it under other blocks.
The Robot is on a stage made of squares that is called a matrix or array. The Robot understands each square as a set of position coordinates. To do this it counts the squares on the X axis (horizontal) and the squares on the Y axis (vertical). The first square is 1,1 the next one to the right is 1,2 and the last square of the first row is 1,5 do you get it?
Sometimes trying is the fastest way to learn.

This is the REPEAT command block.
You can drag it and connect it under other blocks.
This is a special block that "hugs" the command blocks that are connected under it. This is why it has a different color, so you can see the blocks it is connecting.
If the Repeat block connects some blocks the Robot will repeat these commands over and over again. In programming this is called a loop.
To get out of the loop you can use the sensor blocks: when a sensor detects the right number or color it will be released from the repeat loop and will continue the program at the first command after the last command of the loop.

This is the NUMBER command block and it has a different shape because it is a sensor.
You can drag it and connect it to the right of other blocks that have a dent to take it.
This block tells the Robot it has to detect a number. The Robot has a number sensor that detects the last number button that has been pressed, the number buttons are under the Robots color tiled floor.
When you connect a number sensor to another command block the Robot will repeat the command untile it detects the number.
You can learn how to use this block in Mission Three.

This is the COLOR command block and it has a different shape because it is a sensor.
You can drag it and connect it to the right of other blocks that have a dent to take it.
You might have noticed, but the Robot can detect the color of the square it is on. It shows you the color it detects in a little square below his color tiled floor.
When you connect a color sensor to a Repeat command block, the Robot won't stop repeating until it is over a square of the color you have selected. You can select the color you want to detect within the list of colors in the color command block.
You will be able to make the Robot performa a lot of different programs... but carefull about hitting the walls around the colored floor!

This is the SPEED command block.\nYou can drag it and connect it under other blocks.\nIt controls the speed the Robot moves at. The higher the number selected on this block, the faster the Robot will go.
Drag your blocks here to delete them
